title: Routing the Lottery: Adaptive Subnetworks for Heterogeneous Data
summary: Routing the Lottery (RTL) is an adaptive pruning framework that addresses the limitation of the Lottery Ticket Hypothesis by discovering multiple specialized subnetworks, called "adaptive tickets," tailored to heterogeneous data characteristics. This approach consistently outperforms traditional single- and multi-model baselines in accuracy and recall while significantly reducing parameter count and revealing semantically aligned model structures. The work introduces new concepts like subnetwork collapse and a similarity score for diagnosing oversparsification.

title: Early and Prediagnostic Detection of Pancreatic Cancer from Computed Tomography
summary: This paper introduces ePAI, an Artificial Intelligence system designed for early and prediagnostic detection of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) from computed tomography (CT) scans. The system demonstrated high accuracy in both internal and external validation sets, detecting subtle, overlooked lesions up to 36 months before clinical diagnosis. Notably, ePAI significantly outperformed expert radiologists in sensitivity for identifying early PDACs.

title: The Patient is not a Moving Document: A World Model Training Paradigm for Longitudinal EHR
summary: This paper introduces SMB-Structure, a novel 'world model' paradigm for structured Electronic Health Records (EHR) designed to simulate patient dynamics rather than merely summarizing them as static documents. It combines a Joint-Embedding Prediction Architecture (JEPA) with next-token prediction (SFT) to learn embeddings that capture complex disease trajectories. Validated across oncology and pulmonary embolism cohorts, the model demonstrates superior capture of disease dynamics compared to autoregressive baselines, achieving competitive performance on heterogeneous patient tasks.

title: A Federated and Parameter-Efficient Framework for Large Language Model Training in Medicine
summary: This paper introduces Fed-MedLoRA and Fed-MedLoRA+, a novel federated learning framework designed for parameter-efficient and robust adaptation of large language models (LLMs) in medical applications. It addresses key challenges in applying FL to LLMs, namely the high communication and computation overhead of multi-billion parameter models and the inherent heterogeneity of real-world clinical data, by transmitting only low-rank adapter parameters and utilizing data-aware aggregation. The framework's effectiveness is demonstrated for clinical information extraction across diverse patient cohorts and under various real-world evaluation scenarios.

title: Investigating Associational Biases in Inter-Model Communication of Large Generative Models
summary: This paper investigates how social associational biases propagate and amplify in inter-model communication pipelines of large generative AI, focusing on human activity recognition and affective expression. It reveals systematic demographic drifts towards younger representations for both actions and emotions, and more female-presenting representations primarily for emotions, often supported by spurious visual cues. The study highlights the critical need for safeguards and mitigation strategies in human-centered AI systems to prevent unequal treatment stemming from these biases.

title: AIRPET: Virtual Positron Emission Tomography
summary: AIRPET is a novel web-based platform designed to integrate the complex, multi-stage process of Positron Emission Tomography (PET) scanner design into a single, accessible, and AI-assisted workflow. It addresses the challenge of requiring diverse expertise by providing tools for assisted geometry creation via Large Language Models (LLMs) and basic PET image reconstruction. The paper introduces AIRPET, outlining its current functionality and proposed future additions.

title: Hybrid Foveated Path Tracing with Peripheral Gaussians for Immersive Anatomy
summary: This paper introduces a novel hybrid rendering method for high-quality, interactive, and immersive visualization of volumetric medical data. It combines streamed foveated path tracing for high-fidelity central vision with a dynamically generated and refined Gaussian Splatting model for the periphery, enabling rapid updates without extensive preprocessing. The approach improves spatial understanding of complex anatomies for applications like diagnosis and surgical planning.

title: Investigation into using stochastic embedding representations for evaluating the trustworthiness of the Fréchet Inception Distance
summary: This paper investigates the trustworthiness of the Fréchet Inception Distance (FID) for evaluating the quality of synthetic medical images, a metric often considered less effective for this domain due to its reliance on models trained on natural images. The authors utilize Monte Carlo dropout to compute predictive variances in both FID and the underlying feature embeddings, demonstrating a correlation between these variances and the 'out-of-distribution' nature of test inputs. This correlation provides a means to assess the reliability of FID scores in contexts where the feature extractor is mismatched with the data.

title: From Tokens to Blocks: A Block-Diffusion Perspective on Molecular Generation
summary: This paper introduces SoftMol, a novel unified framework designed to overcome limitations in existing GPT-based molecular language models (MLMs) for *de novo* molecular design. SoftMol addresses the inadequate capture of graph-structured molecules and the lack of target-aware generation by proposing a block-diffusion model, SoftBD, using 'soft fragments' and a gated Monte Carlo tree search. The framework achieves superior chemical validity, improved binding affinity, higher molecular diversity, and significantly faster inference compared to state-of-the-art models.

title: From Generative Modeling to Clinical Classification: A GPT-Based Architecture for EHR Notes
summary: This study introduces a GPT-based architecture for clinical text classification that addresses challenges in modeling long EHR notes by employing a selective fine-tuning strategy on a pretrained decoder-only Transformer. By freezing most of the GPT-2 backbone and training only specific final layers and a lightweight classification head, the method achieves strong and efficient performance on radiology reports, particularly adept at handling complex findings like non-mentions and negations.

title: Robust Multimodal Representation Learning in Healthcare
summary: This paper introduces a Dual-Stream Feature Decorrelation Framework to address systematic biases in real-world medical multimodal datasets, which typically hinder the generalization ability of patient representations. By employing structural causal analysis and dual-stream neural networks, the framework disentangles causal features from spurious correlations, leading to more robust patient representations for clinical outcome prediction. Experiments on MIMIC-IV, eICU, and ADNI datasets demonstrate consistent performance improvements.
